children.subject: But you do have a week. You have all (or now most) of dead week. You also don't have to go to class. Given these facts, you can put together a comprehensive day-by-day schedule and plan to tackle certain topics each day for each of your classes.

Yeah but I have a week to prepare for multiple exams + final papers, as opposed to having a week for just one midterm with no other academic commitment. That's why I'm flustered. Plus, most of my dead week goes into having to write final papers + breadth work, so I only get a couple days to study from the whole week. Essentially finals week becomes my dead week. :(

+1. I usually do well on midterms and then end up doing way below average on finals, simply because there is no time to study for all of them as opposed to having a week to prepare for each midterm in advance. Please advise lol

history.content: If you truly don't have time to do it all, I would start by glancing through a past final for each class you are studying for. Then, note what topics you would not be able to solve / unconfident on that seem like are worth a lot of points. For each of these topics, study the lectures, and then attempt the discussion problem relating to that topic without looking at solutions. Same with homework. The truth is that studying for finals a week before is super hard because you have not just one test, but multiple, and they're 3 hours long each. There's no shortcut, but if you want to do as best as possible just rank by how much you don't know something at all, because knowing a little of a lot is often better than knowing a few topics super well.

children.subject: these are great tips, but i find practice exams get less and less useful as you get to upper divs / increasingly hard classes. When the class size isn't 1000, then the exams are less about practicing taking the exam and more about honing your first principles from hw/dis

If the course has a lot of practice exams available and I have kept up with the material:

1) Make cheat sheet first, by going through lectures and writing down pertinent information. Since I already learned the material during the semester, I don't need to relearn anything, I just need to remember that I learned it. So making the cheat sheet, writing down formulas and theorems turns the spade in the soil of my head. 

2) With most of the material fresh in my memory, I just start taking practice tests. Most importantly, after I take them, I also throughly correct them - for each question I got wrong, why did I get it wrong and why is the solution right? For each question I got stuck on, do I understand the solution? What line of thinking would have gotten me unstuck during the exam? (oftentimes its because I was trying to prove a statement in one direction but didn't realize the backwards direction was much easier). While correcting these tests I often find extra facts that I didn't know (subtle things) and add them to my cheat sheet. 

3) Repeat step 2 until you either run out of practice tests or you get sick of taking them (I usually reach the latter first which is when I stop)

Personally, just taking practice tests helps me study because it gets me familiar with the format of test, helps me discover what topic I am really shaky on (which I then go to OH/Piazza to fix), and just practice, practice, practice

If there aren't a ton of practice exams available, then I try to go through old discussion and homework problems, but those are much less useful because I have seen them before :(

history.content: This might seem like a silly question but I still feel like I don't know how to effectively study for cs finals here at Berkeley. I usually try to go over all the past discussions and then just work on practice exams, but honestly don't know if this has helped me on finals as it's hard to essentially re-learn the entire semester in a week. It's also super overwhelming to try and cram in so much material into such a short amount of time. So if anyone has any tips/effective strategies that they have found helpful for finals studying (specifically CS courses) please share! Thanks in advance and good luck to everyone with studying :) <3
history.subject: how to study for cs finals?
